bibl.title: Letter from E.A. Sweet to Henry Rose Carter, May 3, 1923

div1.p: Sweet discusses the introduction of mosquitoes to Hawaii in 1829 and the prevalence of fever there.

div1.head: Letter from E.A. Sweet to Henry Rose Carter, May 3, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Australia
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
HONOLULU QUARANTINE STATION
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
HONOLULU
May 3, 1923.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter of May 3rd arrived yesterday and in order to lessen dis-
tance delay I am replying promptly, only setting down what little knowledge
I have in my head.

Mosquitoes, until 1829, were unknown to the Hawaiians. The missionaries
came in 1820 and the mosquitoes nine years later. I believe that the latter
have been by far the greater pest but certain authorities seem to question this.
However they have both been present since that date. The vessel which first
brought mosquitoes here is perfectly well known and came from the west coast of
Mexico, calling at the then important whaling port of Lahaina, on the island
of Maui. From there thay soon spread to the remaining islands of the group.
It is interesting to note that the Hawaiians had no word in their language for
mosquito and the nearest they could come to the English pronunciation was
“makiká”, so that that word is now Hawaiian for mosquito.

In many sections of the Islands conditions for mosquito development
have been ideal. There are large swampy areas, until recently even in the
midst of the city of Honolulu, and there are even swamps on the mountain tops.
Rice has been, and still is, cultivated extensively and in the older days every
Hawaiian had his taro patch, this vegetable being grown in much the same manner
as rice. Householders depended upon barrels for their water supply, and do
yet to a certain extent. There is no marked seasonal inhibition as the ther-
mometer at sea-level seldom gets below sixty. Dragon flies are plentiful, in
fact I think they are more numerous here than in any place I have ever been,
and they must account for the destruction of large numbers of mosquitoes.

As far as I am aware we have never had but three varieties. Aedes
aegypti, Culex fatigans, and I think, altho I am not sure, S. scutellaris.
Some two or three years ago in an old report I read that Aedes aegypti made
up about ten per cent of the mosquito population. Perhaps the percentage has
since decreased or possibly the original estimate was in error; certainly they
seem to be plentiful enough at present. Anopheles have never been intro-
duced, a strange fact, even after making due allowance for their habits.
Ideal conditions for their propagation exist on all the islands and if a pair
of them could find their way on some vessel at a California or other port,
or stow away in a trunk, malaria in a short time would be rampant. Have you
an explanation to offer? I have always thought that some day they would be
introduced. I might add that everything else under God's green heavens has
found a refuge here, to the great detriment of the agricultural interests, but
of late years a very strict plant quarantine has been maintained. Roses were
everywhere in former days but the Japanese beetle came in and now it is almost
impossible to grow them except under an electric light. And so it is with the
leaf hopper, the cane borer and the Mediterranean fruit fly. As fast as they
have arrived, however, the planters have sent their entomologists to all parts
of the world in search of their natural enemies and the success of the sugar
industry to-day is the outcome of their investigations. But I am digressing.
I was referring to malaria. The practitioners here never see it and when an
imported case does come to their attention it is seldom diagnosed immediately.
One of our officers had an interesting case of fever some time ago. Half a
dozen of the physisians in town saw it and all sorts of diagnoses were entered,
enteris, sepsis, sinus trouble, etc. Parasites were plentiful. On the other
hand the doctors here recognize leprosy when they see it and when one of them
goes to a skin clinic in the East he can often point out, even to the derma-
tologists, cases of leprosy which have been treated for something else.

As to yellow fever, we have never had a case except the two, which you
know more about than I. Dengue, however, has been present and a dozen or more
years ago an epidemic of several thousand cases swept the Islands. Can you
conceive of any reason why yellow fever should not do likewise? Aedes must be
present in all coast towns, although lacking information furnished by a survey
this statement may appear a bit wild. Still, I think it is a reasonable con-
clusion. It would be interesting to see at what levels they were found, for
as you know, our coast is narrow and we have mountains that reach about as high
as any in the states. As far as yellow fever is concerned our greatest danger
probably comes from the west coast of Mexico. Vessels coming up from Panama
and the west coast of South America frequently call at Manzanillo and other
ports but we are continuing our precautions.

For some time I have had a suspicion that filariasis was more or less
indigenous. Of course we meet with occasional cases in Filipinos and Asiatics
but I would not be surprised if it were even more common. No survey has ever
been made, as far as I am aware. Perhaps if this were done we might find a
situation such as exists around old Charleston. I neglected to mention that
several years ago Doctor Ludlow, who receives specimens from the Army sent from
here, thought that she had an Anopheles. The specimen was macerated and she
was unable to decide definitely. According to Colonel Craig, who is now here,
this incident has been repeated recently. I have not seen Craig to question
him regarding it but I would suggest, inasmuch as you are in Washington, that
you call up Doctor Ludlow and ascertain the facts from her. It is of course a
matter of great importance to us.

Our station stenographer is on leave and this affair I fear is rambling.
I wish too itmxx were a trifle more scientific. Perhaps though you can get a
general impression of our situation. When I sit down to a machine I am apt to
write much as I would talk, making mention of this, that, and the other. I note
that you sign yourself “on waiting orders”. That being the case couldn't you
find time to run out this way and look us over? I know of no more attractive
spot. Once since I have been here the thermometer has reached 85.5 and the
coldest I have seen it at Honolulu has been 60, not an extensive range as you
will note. People find it a bit depressing after a time and usually go to the
coast to recuperate but it is nothing like the tropics.
